bestBHT.bht: The chief of the Jews, along with the high priest, kept beseeching Festus against Paul. Their persistence in renewing the charge after two years reveals their undying enmity towards Paul and the significance they attributed to his influence. In an attempt to bias Festus against Paul, the leading men of the city, including the chief priests, joined in the beseeching, laying numerous heavy accusations against him. Their intention was to prepossess and prejudice the governor against Paul by highlighting his alleged wickedness and the evils he had supposedly committed.

Henry Alford: The term chief of the Jews is more general than 'elders,' though most of the chief men must have been members of the Sanhedrim."
Festus, relating this application, ver. 15, calls them 'elders.'
The High Priest now was Ishmael the son of Phabi.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: successor of him before whom Paul had appeared ( :-).
and the chief of the Jews—and
"the whole multitude of the Jews" ( :-) clamorously.
Albert Barnes: It is evident that there was here every probability that injustice would be done to Paul, and that the mind of Festus would be biased against him.
He was a stranger to Paul, and to the embittered feelings of the Jewish character. He would wish to conciliate their favor upon entering into the duties of his office.
A strong representation, therefore, made by the chief men of the nation, would be likely to prejudice him violently against Paul, and to unfit him for the exercise of impartial justice.
Marvin Vincent: Besought. The imperfect denotes their persistence : kept beseeching.
Philip Schaff: The majority of the older MSS., instead of ‘high priest’ read here ‘chief priests,’ including the ‘chiefs of the priestly courses,’ and not improbably those who had for a longer or shorter period filled the office themselves of high priest.
If the reading ‘high priest’ be correct, the name of this high official here referred to would be Ismael the son of Plato, who had very recently been appointed to that dignity by Herod Agrippa II.

It is clear that, owing to the machinations of his sleepless enemies, a very strong hostile feeling to the great Gentile apostle had sprung up, of which this ‘information’ and ‘petition’ to the new procurator was the result.
Archibald T. Robertson: This renewal of the charge after two years, on the very first opportunity, is a measure, not only of their unsleeping hatred, but of the importance which they attached to Paul's influence.
The first men, the leading men of the city, besides the chief priests.
They kept on beseeching as a special favor to the Jews.
John Gill: They laid many things to his charge, and very heavily accused him, and endeavoured to prepossess the governor, and prejudice him against him.
They took the first opportunity of waiting upon him, when he was come to Jerusalem; hoping it might be a favourable one to them.
They brought a bill of information against Paul, and gave a large account of him, what a wicked man he was, and what evils he had committed.

bhtAttempts.bht: The chief of the Jews, along with the high priest, persistently besought Festus to take action against Paul. Their renewal of the charge after two years demonstrates both their unrelenting hatred towards Paul and the importance they attached to his influence. The chief men of the city, including the chief priests, joined in with the beseeching, hoping to bias Festus against Paul. They laid many heavy accusations against him, hoping to prepossess the governor and prejudice him against Paul's case. It is evident that their intention was to bring harm to Paul by giving a large account of his wickedness and the evils he had committed.

Their renewal of the charge after two years demonstrates both their unrelenting hatred towards Paul and the importance they attached to his influence. The chief men of the city, including the chief priests, joined in with the beseeching, hoping to bias Festus against Paul. They laid many heavy accusations against him, hoping to prepossess the governor and prejudice him against Paul's case.

Their renewal of the charge after two years demonstrates both their unrelenting hatred towards Paul and the importance they attached to his influence. The chief men of the city, including the chief priests, joined in with the beseeching, hoping to bias Festus against Paul. They laid many heavy accusations against him, hoping to prepossess the governor and prejudice him against Paul's case.

The chief of the Jews, along with the high priest, kept beseeching Festus against Paul. Their persistence in renewing the charge after two years reveals their undying enmity towards Paul and the significance they attributed to his influence. In an attempt to bias Festus against Paul, the leading men of the city, including the chief priests, joined in the beseeching, laying numerous heavy accusations against him. Their intention was to prepossess and prejudice the governor against Paul by highlighting his alleged wickedness and the evils he had supposedly committed.

The chief of the Jews, along with the high priest, persisted in beseeching Festus against Paul. Their unrelenting animosity towards him and the value they placed on his influence is evident in their insistence on renewing the charge after two years. The leading men of the city, including the chief priests, joined in, aiming to bias Festus against Paul by laying multiple heavy accusations. Their goal was to prepossess and prejudice the governor, emphasizing Paul's alleged wickedness and the evils he had committed.
